adjective.description: (of food) recently made or obtained; not canned, frozen, or otherwise preserved.
Not previously known or used; new or different.
examples: the court had heard fresh evidence

adjective.description: (of a person) full of energy and vigor.
examples: they are feeling fresh after a good night's sleep
all the fresh water in the world's lakes

adjective.description: (of the wind) cool and fairly strong.
examples: a fresh northerly wind was speeding the ship southwards

adjective.description: (of a person) having just had (a particular experience) or come from (a particular place)
examples: we were fresh out of art school

adjective.description: Presumptuous toward someone, especially in a sexual way.
examples: one truck driver decided to get fresh with me

adjective.description: (of a cow) yielding a renewed or increased supply of milk following the birth of a calf.

phrases: He was fresh out of ideas, and his next move could be checkmate.
Or you may be fresh out of layout ideas and may glean some inspiration by starting with a basic page.
The only problem with that was Peter was fresh out of inspiration.
It's possible that he is fresh out of constructive ideas on this subject.
If you had to check your camera, you likely would have been fresh out of luck on that trip.
origin: Old English fersc not salt, fit for drinking, superseded in Middle English by forms from Old French freis, fresche; both ultimately of Germanic origin and related to Dutch vers and German frisch.
